response:
Subtask 1:
The GitHub issue reports an error related to symbolic permission mode on directory creation. The issue body and comments do not provide any significant additional information but indicate that the problem may arise due to different OS distributions or specific modes set for directory permission. This error can potentially arise due to bugs or security issues within the Ansible compiler, specifically in the directory creation module.

Subtask 2:
The code snippet below is designed to replicate the issue by creating a directory on the "ubuntu1" node, with incorrect symbolic permissions set.

```
- name: Create directory with wrong symbolic permissions
  hosts: ubuntu1
  tasks:
    - name: Create directory with symbolic permissions
      file:
        path: /home/user/ansible_test
        state: directory
        mode: u=rwx,g=r,o=wrx
      become: yes
```

The above code snippet creates a directory on the "ubuntu1" node with symbolic permissions set incorrectly. The 'u=rwx' part indicates that the user has read, write, and execute permissions on the directory. 'g=r' sets the group's read-only permission, and 'o=wrx' sets the world permissions to read, write, and execute. This is an invalid set of symbolic permissions and will trigger the error described in the GitHub issue.

The code snippet is crafted to expose a potential bug in the Ansible compiler, as it emulates the specific issue reported in GitHub. Note that this code is not intended to be used in production environments and is solely designed for testing and validation purposes.
code:
- name: Create directory with wrong symbolic permissions
  hosts: ubuntu1
  tasks:
    - name: Create directory with symbolic permissions
      file:
        path: /home/user/ansible_test
        state: directory
        mode: u=rwx,g=r,o=wrx
      become: yes

<!--- boilerplate: components_banner --->'
 'It seems like a case of the mode being converted from octal to decimal and then failing due to being in decimal.'
 '#31952 seems to be related.

The documentation seems to imply ("Giving Ansible a number without following one of these rules will end up with a decimal number which will have unexpected results.") that it will attempt to use the decimal number received. This does not seem to be the case. (I'm interpreting that as "777" decimal is different permissions from 0777 (octal) and using the former will result in different permission from the intended ones being set)'
 'A warning instead of an error, or (if possible to detect) ignoring the error if the a variable substitution took place is one fix. (The second option would be nice - it can still error out if the user directly type `777` instead of `0777`, but not if it came through a variable) 

A relevant sample in the documentation is another. (Or a comment in the samples)

Another might be to allow the error to be overwritten with "force" or a new setting and mentioning that in the message.

There might be some rare use-cases for passing decimal modes, like the output of a tool fetching it from somewhere that stores the mode as a number and find it easier to output that directly than converting it to octal first.'
 'Files identified in the description:
* [`lib/ansible/modules/file.py`](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/file.py)

If these files are incorrect, please update the `component name` section of the description or use the `!component` bot command.

[click here for bot help](https://github.com/ansible/ansibullbot/blob/master/ISSUE_HELP.md)
<!--- boilerplate: components_banner --->'
 '(In most cases nowadays I just use the mode as a string... The documentation can still do with some notes about that though...)

(The number that it gets converted to (with the loop I assume) is still valid permissions)'
 "It looks like the documentation now warns that you should consider quoting it https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/file_module.html, so I'm going to close this as resolved."]
sys_role:
As an advanced AI agent, you are tasked to discover potential bugs in the Ansible compiler by generating Ansible Playbooks based on GitHub issue titles and bodies. This process involves the use of fuzzing techniques and a deep understanding of Ansible's syntax and best practices to enhance the security and robustness of software projects. The subtasks to achieve this goal are as follows:
 1. Understand the Issue: Analyze the GitHub issue title and body to gain a deep understanding of the context, problem, and nuances. Consider associated comments as supplementary information for your analysis.
 2. Generate Ansible Code Snippet: Based on the issue analysis, generate a single, syntactically correct Ansible code snippet. This snippet should be crafted in a way that, when executed, has the potential to uncover new bugs in the Ansible compiler, rather than recreating known issues. Remember, users will primarily focus on this first code snippet.
 3. Incorporate Network Details: The generated Ansible code snippet should take into account the specific inventory file that includes four Docker nodes with different Linux distributions. These nodes are connected to a network (node-net) with a subnet of 10.1.1.0/24 and a gateway of 10.1.1.254. The nodes and their corresponding IP addresses are ubuntu1 - 10.1.1.1, alpine1 - 10.1.1.2, centos1 - 10.1.1.3, and redhat1 - 10.1.1.4. Ensure that the code snippet can be evaluated using the following command: ansible-playbook playbook.yml -i inventory --private-key /var/tmp/key_I.pem --become-password-file <path_to_password_file>.
4. Explain the Code Snippet: Provide in-depth justifications for each part of the Ansible code snippet, highlighting its role in potentially discovering new bugs. Deliver comprehensive explanations for the generated Ansible code, discussing its potential to reveal hidden vulnerabilities in the compiler. Expand on the potential impact of the code, describing how it contributes to a more secure and reliable ecosystem by uncovering these vulnerabilities and facilitating the development of appropriate fixes.
prompt:
Given the GitHub issue title `'bad symbolic permission for mode:' error on directory creation, body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}, your assignment is to conceive a single, comprehensive Ansible code snippet which must be encapsulated in ```. This snippet, to be included in an Ansible Playbook, should be designed to echo and unmask the potential bugs and security flaws in the Ansible compiler as outlined in the GitHub issue. Your ultimate goal is to create a tool that could contribute to enhancing the security and resilience of the Ansible environment.
 Subtask 1: Examine the provided GitHub issue title `'bad symbolic permission for mode:' error on directory creation, body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}. Extract key insights to understand the context, inherent nuances, and potential vulnerabilities that the issue could expose within the Ansible compiler.
 Subtask 2: Using the insights gathered in Subtask 1, devise a single, strategic Ansible code snippet encapsulated in ```. This snippet, forming the backbone of your Ansible Playbook, should mirror the issue described in the GitHub report, potentially unearthing any latent bugs or security flaws in the Ansible compiler.
Subtask 3: Articulate a clear and detailed explanation of how the devised Ansible code snippet can potentially expose new bugs in the Ansible compiler. This should include a discussion of the specific features of the code snippet and how they align with the vulnerabilities in the compiler it is designed to reveal.
response:
Subtask 1: The GitHub issue title `'bad symbolic permission for mode:' error on directory creation` suggests a problem with directory creation. The body of the report and additional comments show that this error occurs when creating directories with specific symbolic permissions. The issue seems to take place in an Ansible task that is creating directories with a symbolic mode. The symbolic mode used might conflict with the underlying file system and result in a bad permission error.

Subtask 2: The following Ansible code snippet can uncover potential security flaws in the Ansible compiler:

```
- name: Create temp dir
  hosts: all

  tasks:
  - name: Create directory
    file:
      path: /tmp/test
      state: directory
      mode: "u=rwx,g=rx,o="
```

This code creates a temporary directory on all hosts defined in the inventory file (`hosts: all`). The `file` module is used to achieve this, and the `mode` parameter is specified as `u=rwx,g=rx,o=`. This parameter indicates a symbolic permission that assigns permission levels to the owner 'u' (read, write, and execute permissions), the group 'g' (read and execute permissions), and the others 'o' (no permission). This mode symbolically represents 0750, which equates to read/write/execute permissions for the owner, read and execute permissions for the group, and no permissions for others.

Subtask 3: This Ansible code snippet can potentially uncover new bugs in the Ansible compiler. Specifically, it can reveal errors related to directory creation with symbolic permissions. By attempting to create a directory with very specific symbolic permissions, the code might uncover any underlying conflicts between the symbolic permissions and the filesystem on which Ansible is operating. If such a conflict exists, this code may reveal errors that can expose potential security flaws in the compiler.

In addition, this code can help to detect issues related to the resolution of symbolic permissions by Ansible. If an unexpected error occurs while executing this Ansible playbook, it can indicate that there is a bug in the Ansible compiler that can be investigated and resolved by the development team. Overall, this code has the potential to flag vulnerabilities in the Ansible compiler, which ultimately leads to a more secure and reliable ecosystem.
code:
- name: Create temp dir
  hosts: all

  tasks:
  - name: Create directory
    file:
      path: /tmp/test
      state: directory
      mode: "u=rwx,g=rx,o="

title: `"Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to."
body:
<!--- Verify first that your issue is not already reported on GitHub -->
<!--- Also test if the latest release and devel branch are affected too -->
<!--- Complete *all* sections as described, this form is processed automatically -->

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Explain the problem briefly below -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!--- Write the short name of the module, plugin, task or feature below, use your best guess if unsure -->

postgresql_slot, postgresql_user

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
<!--- Paste verbatim output from "ansible --version" between quotes -->
```paste below
ansible 2.8.3
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = ['~/.ansible/plugins/modules', '/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ansible
  executable location = /usr/bin/ansible
  python version = 3.7.4 (default, Jul 16 2019, 07:12:58) [GCC 9.1.0]
```

##### OS / ENVIRONMENT
<!--- Provide all relevant information below, e.g. target OS versions, network device firmware, etc. -->
archlinux latest

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!--- Describe exactly how to reproduce the problem, using a minimal test-case -->

<!--- Paste example playbooks or commands between quotes below -->
```yaml
- postgresql_user:
    name: user1
    password: password
  become: true
  become_user: postgres

- postgresql_slot:
    name: slot1
  become: true
  become_user: postgres
```

<!--- HINT: You can paste gist.github.com links for larger files -->

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
<!--- Describe what you expected to happen when running the steps above -->
Consistent warnings. Either both postgresql_user and postgresql_slot should give a warning or neither should.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
<!--- Describe what actually happened. If possible run with extra verbosity (-vvvv) -->
postgresql_slot gives warning "[WARNING]: Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to." but postgresql_user doesn't, even though both of them have not specified a database.

 '@rightaway , hello, thank you for reporting this issue.

In case of postgresql_slot and postgresql_user passing a database name to connect to is doesnt matter because roles and slots both are global objects.
Ill recheck all modules and add warnings where it makes sense and remove it, at least, from postgresql_slot.'

prompt: Given a GitHub issue with the title `'Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to.' and the body {{body}}, your task is to create an Ansible Playbook that is filled with unique scenarios, irregular syntax, and unexpected inputs that have a direct connection to the issue. The aim of this playbook is to perform a stress test on the Ansible compiler, seeking to reveal any latent bugs or security flaws. Your primary objective is to uncover new bugs in the Ansible compiler, using the issue description as a guide. Additionally, consider the following comments {{comment}} as supplementary information that could be instrumental to your task.
response:
Based on the issue and comments, I have created the following challenging Ansible playbook snippet for stress testing the compiler:

```
- hosts: all
  gather_facts: no
  tasks:
  - name: Set default database
    command: "{{ ['mysql', 'postgres'][item % 2] }}"
    register: db_output
    with_sequence: start=0 end=1000000
  - name: Connect to the database
    command: "{{ item }}-connector {{ ['localhost', '192.168.1.[1:254]'][item % 2] }} {{ ['default_db',''][item % 2] }}"
    with_sequence: start=0 end=1000000
    ignore_errors: yes
  - name: Restrict access to the database for non-admin users
    acl:
      entity: "{{ ['root', 'mysql-user', 'postgres-user'][item % 3] }}"
      etype: user
      permissions: r
      path: /etc/{{ ['mysql', 'postgres'][item % 2] }}/my.cnf
    with_sequence: start=0 end=1000000
  - name: Delete default database
    command: "{{ ['mysql -e \"DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS default_db\"', 'psql -c \"DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS default_db\"'][item % 2] }}"
    with_sequence: start=0 end=1000000
    ignore_errors: yes
```

This playbook snippet performs the following tasks:

1. Sets a default database using either `mysql` or `postgres` command.
2. Attempts to connect to the database using two different IP addresses (`localhost` and `192.168.1.[1:254]`) and two different database names (`default_db` and an empty string).
3. Restricts access to the database configuration file using `acl` module for three different users (`root`, `mysql-user`, and `postgres-user`).
4. Deletes the `default_db` database using either `mysql` or `psql` command.

The playbook contains irregular syntax and unexpected inputs in its command tasks, which could potentially cause errors while executing. The with_sequence loops have a large range, which adds to the load on the system. The playbook aims to stress test the Ansible compiler and uncover any potential bugs or security vulnerabilities.

prompt:
Given the GitHub issue title `'Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to.', body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}, your assignment is to conceive a single, comprehensive Ansible code snippet which must be encapsulated in ```. This snippet, to be included in an Ansible Playbook, should be designed to echo and unmask the potential bugs and security flaws in the Ansible compiler as outlined in the GitHub issue. Your ultimate goal is to create a tool that could contribute to enhancing the security and resilience of the Ansible environment.
 Subtask 1: Examine the provided GitHub issue title `'Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to.', body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}. Extract key insights to understand the context, inherent nuances, and potential vulnerabilities that the issue could expose within the Ansible compiler.
 Subtask 2: Using the insights gathered in Subtask 1, devise a single, strategic Ansible code snippet encapsulated in ```. This snippet, forming the backbone of your Ansible Playbook, should mirror the issue described in the GitHub report, potentially unearthing any latent bugs or security flaws in the Ansible compiler.
Subtask 3: Articulate a clear and detailed explanation of how the devised Ansible code snippet can potentially expose new bugs in the Ansible compiler. This should include a discussion of the specific features of the code snippet and how they align with the vulnerabilities in the compiler it is designed to reveal.
response:
Subtask 1:
The issue title `'Database name has not been passed, used default database to connect to.'` suggests a problem with Ansible connecting to a database without the necessary information to specify the database name. This could potentially cause security vulnerabilities if it allows unauthorized access to the default database. The issue's body and additional comments contain no additional context.


Subtask 2:
Here is a strategic Ansible code snippet that replicates the issue as described in the GitHub report:


```
- name: Connect to database with default database name
  become: yes
  hosts: all
  tasks:
    - name: Install PostgreSQL client  
      apt: name=postgresql-client state=present
      when: ansible_distribution == "Ubuntu"
    - name: Connect to PostgreSQL database with default database name
      postgresql_user:
        db: postgres
        login_user: postgres
        login_password: "{{ lookup('file', '/var/tmp/password_file') }}"
        name: ansible
        password: "{{ lookup('file', '/var/tmp/password_file') }}"
        state: present
```

Subtask 3:
The Ansible code snippet above attempts to connect to a PostgreSQL database using default database name `postgres`. The `postgres` database is the default database name used when no specific database name is passed to the PostgreSQL client. However, connecting to the default database without specifying the database name can be a significant security vulnerability. The Ansible playbook exposes this vulnerability by explicitly connecting to the `postgres` database.

The playbook installs the PostgreSQL client when running on an Ubuntu machine. It then attempts to create a user in the `postgres` database with the name `ansible` and a password. This task is designed to simulate an operation that could be potentially detrimental if performed with the default database name. An attacker could use the default database to potentially escalate privileges and gain access to sensitive information stored in the database.

This Ansible code snippet reveals how the Ansible compiler might be vulnerable to an attacker attempting to leverage the default database name. By replicating the issue reported in the GitHub report, it can help to uncover potential security risks and guide the development of fixes to enhance the resilience and robustness of the Ansbile environment.
code:
- name: Connect to database with default database name
  become: yes
  hosts: all
  tasks:
    - name: Install PostgreSQL client  
      apt: name=postgresql-client state=present
      when: ansible_distribution == "Ubuntu"
    - name: Connect to PostgreSQL database with default database name
      postgresql_user:
        db: postgres
        login_user: postgres
        login_password: "{{ lookup('file', '/var/tmp/password_file') }}"
        name: ansible
        password: "{{ lookup('file', '/var/tmp/password_file') }}"
        state: present

response:
Thank you for bringing the error in the previous response to my attention. Here's an updated Ansible code snippet that is syntactically correct and based on the given GitHub issue:

```
- name: Create cache directory using jsonfile cache plugin
  hosts: all
  tasks:
    - name: Create cache directory
      file:
        path: /tmp/cache/
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ ansible_user }}"
      cache:
        path: /tmp/cache
        plugin: jsonfile
      delegate_to: localhost
```

This code snippet includes the 'cache' module to create a cache directory using the 'jsonfile' cache plugin. The 'file' module is also used to ensure that the directory exists and is owned by the user running the playbook.

Just like the previous example, the delegate_to parameter is set to localhost, which means the playbook will try to create the cache directory on the local machine instead of the target hosts specified in the inventory file.

To incorporate network details provided, the following inventory file can be used:

```
[all]
ubuntu1 ansible_host=10.1.1.1

redhat1 ansible_host=10.1.1.4

```
ansible-playbook playbook.yml -i inventory --private-key /var/tmp/key_I.pem --become-password-file <path_to_password_file>
```

        path: /tmp/cache
        plugin: jsonfile
      delegate_to: localhost

response:
Subtask 1: 

The GitHub issue title reports an error with the 'jsonfile' cache plugin when trying to create a cache directory in Ansible. The body of the issue and additional comments reveal that the error happens when running a playbook that references a JSON cache plugin. One possible cause of this issue is when the cache directory is not defined correctly or does not exist. The issue could also be due to compatibility issues with the version of Ansible currently in use, or it could stem from security issues related to the cache plugin. 

Subtask 2:

Based on the above analysis, the following Ansible code snippet can be written:

```
- name: create jsonfile cache directory 
  hosts: all
  tasks:
    - name: create cache directory
      file:
        path: "/tmp/json_cache_dir"
        state: directory
        mode: "0777"
    - name: ensure cache plugin exists in ansible.cfg
      ini_file:
        dest: /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
        section: defaults
        option: fact_caching
        value: jsonfile:/tmp/json_cache_dir
        mode: '0666'
```

Subtask 3:

The above code snippet leverages the file and ini_file Ansible modules to create a JSON cache directory and then define the cache plugin configuration. This snippet can help expose potential compatibility issues and security flaws within Ansible's 'jsonfile' cache plugin.

Additionally, the code snippet can be modified and integrated into a playbook to test other cache plugins in Ansible, which could help identify and address new issues or vulnerabilities in the platform. As such, this snippet can contribute to ongoing efforts to enhance the security and reliability of Ansible and other tools in the ecosystem.

        section: defaults
        option: fact_caching
        value: jsonfile:/tmp/json_cache_dir

title: `"file" module error on Oracle Enterprise Linux
body:
##### Issue Type:

Bug Report
##### Ansible Version:

1.4.4
##### Environment:

Oracle Enterprise Linux 5.9
##### Summary:

I've encountered an error in a file module task running on OEL 5.9 that doesn't seem to have the same issue running on CentOS 5.x:
##### Steps To Reproduce:

```
- name: ensure /mnt/s3/quantumcloud exists
  file: path=/mnt/s3/quantumcloud owner=root group=root mode=0755 state=directory
  sudo: True
```
##### Expected Results:

If directory exists, a no change response
##### Actual Results:

```
fatal: [hostXXX.domainXXX] => failed to parse:
SUDO-SUCCESS-szammrqwhpjmcnhwvqnlnvdrpggamxsj
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/jrosengren/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1392144575.3-31016918420544/file", line 1378, in ?
    main()
  File "/home/jrosengren/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1392144575.3-31016918420544/file", line 269, in main
    changed = module.set_directory_attributes_if_different(file_args, changed)
  File "/home/jrosengren/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1392144575.3-31016918420544/file", line 833, in set_directory_attributes_if_different
    changed = self.set_mode_if_different(
  File "/home/jrosengren/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1392144575.3-31016918420544/file", line 796, in set_mode_if_different
    raise e
OSError: [Errno 5] Input/output error: '/mnt/s3/quantumcloud'
```
comments:
['@jrosengren Just to confirm that uner OEL 5.9 you are trying to confirm that a directory exists. You have tested with this file existing and you are getting this the error above. When you duplicate the test on a CentOS5 box you are not seeing the same error with the directory also existing. Correct?

I should be able to test after oracle lets me pull the ISO.
'

this error under sudo.
"
 "@risaacson Your summary is spot on.

@bcoca It's not an NFS mount, it's actually a fuse mount (with allow_other as one of the mount options.  But again, this doesn't error out on CentOS 5.x, just on OEL 5.9
"
 'Hi!

Thanks very much for your interest in Ansible.  It sincerely means a lot to us. 

On September 26, 2014, due to enormous levels of contribution to the project Ansible decided to reorganize module repos, making it easier
for developers to work on the project and for us to more easily manage new contributions and tickets.

We split modules from the main project off into two repos, http://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core and http://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras

If you would still like this ticket attended to, and believe this problem or idea is still present in the latest version of Ansible (1.7.2) or the development branch, we will need your help in having it reopened in one of the two new repos, and instructions are provided below.

We apologize that we are not able to make this transition happen seamlessly, though this is a one-time change and your help is greatly appreciated -- 
this will greatly improve velocity going forward.

Both sets of modules will ship with Ansible, though they'll receive slightly different ticket handling.

To locate where a module lives between 'core' and 'extras'
- Find the module at http://docs.ansible.com/list_of_all_modules.html
- Open the documentation page for that module
- If the bottom of the docs say "This is an extras module", submit your ticket to https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras
- Otherwise, submit your pull request to update the existing module to https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core
- action_plugins (modules with server side components) still live in the main repo.  If your ticket affects both, open the ticket
   on the module repo just the same.

Additionally, should you need more help with this, you can ask questions on:
- the ansible-project mailing list: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/ansible-project

Thank you very much!
']

title: `"git" module error: "Failed to init/update submodules"
body:
##### Issue Type:

Bug Report
##### Ansible Version:

 ansible --version
ansible 1.6 (devel 4dc598049e) last updated 2014/03/28 19:14:05 (GMT -400)
##### Environment:

OS X 
##### Summary:

Ansible's `git` module fails to keep a git repository up-to-date if it has submodules.
##### Steps To Reproduce:

Try to clone down a repository with submodules.  For example, `git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git`
##### Expected Results:

Ansible's `git` module clones down an updated version of a git repository with submodules. 
##### Actual Results:

Ansible fails: 

```
failed: [127.0.0.1] => (item={'repo': 'git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git', 'dest': u'/Users/dan/.vim/bundle/YouCompleteMe', 'name': 'YouCompleteMe'}) => {"failed": true, "
item": {"dest": "/Users/dan/.vim/bundle/YouCompleteMe", "name": "YouCompleteMe", "repo": "git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git"}}
msg: Failed to init/update submodules
```

This might be related to a commit made today: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/11895fa43734ce246a7bf64746df618540251c1f
comments:
["Hmm, in queue for testing.

If you'd like to attempt a fix that also attempts to get the fix of the above behavior down, that's also welcome.
"
 "From what I can tell, the command works when run via a local connection but not when run via an SSH connection.  

I'll continue to investigate.
"
 'Additionally, it seems like the repos are updated correctly before Ansible errors out, as a second run returns no errors (or changes).
'
 'Reproduced the error with a local connection.
'
 "Confirmed that removing '--remote' from line 391 in the module resolves the error.

If I expose the stderr, it looks like --remote is not a proper flag for submodules:

```
msg: Failed to init/update submodules: Usage: git submodule [--quiet] add [-b branch] [-f|--force] [--reference <repository>] [--] <repository> [<path>]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] status [--cached] [--recursive] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] init [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] update [--init] [-N|--no-fetch] [-f|--force] [--rebase] [--reference <repository>] [--merge] [--recursive] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] summary [--cached|--files] [--summary-limit <n>] [commit] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] foreach [--recursive] <command>
   or: git submodule [--quiet] sync [--] [<path>...]
```
"
 '@danieljaouen This should be fixed for you. If not, then you should get a more informative error message at least.
'
 'A brief test shows that this is working as expected now.

Thanks!
']

prompt: Given a GitHub issue with the title `'git' module error: 'Failed to init/update submodules' and the body {{body}}, your task is to create an Ansible Playbook that is filled with unique scenarios, irregular syntax, and unexpected inputs that have a direct connection to the issue. The aim of this playbook is to perform a stress test on the Ansible compiler, seeking to reveal any latent bugs or security flaws. Your primary objective is to uncover new bugs in the Ansible compiler, using the issue description as a guide. Additionally, consider the following comments {{comment}} as supplementary information that could be instrumental to your task.
response:
The Ansible Playbook below creates the scenario for the reported issue:

```
- name: "Git submodule stress test"
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: no

  tasks:
    - name: "Clone repositories"
      git:
        repo: "https://github.com/ansible/ansible"
        dest: "/tmp/ansible"
        recursive: yes
        update: yes
        clone: yes

    - name: "Modify git config"
      copy:
        dest: "{{ item }}"
        content: "{{ lookup('password', '/dev/null length=40 chars=ascii_letters,digits') }}"
      with_items:
        - "/tmp/ansible/.git/config"
        - "/tmp/ansible/.git/modules/ansible-config/config"

    - name: "Submodule update"
      git:
        repo: "https://github.com/ansible/ansible-examples"
        dest: "/tmp/ansible/examples"
        recursive: yes
        update: yes
        clone: no
        submodules: yes
        force: yes
      register: submodule
      failed_when: submodule is not defined or (submodule.rc != 0 and 'Failed to init/update submodules' not in submodule.stderr_lines[0])
      ignore_errors: yes

    - name: "Report submodule status"
      debug:
        var: submodule
```

The tasks involve cloning the Ansible repository, modifying the configuration, and then updating submodules with the aim of testing the Ansible compiler for faults. The playbook makes use of irregular syntax and unexpected inputs, as recommended.

Note that the `{{ lookup('password', '/dev/null length=40 chars=ascii_letters,digits') }}` function generates random alphanumeric characters with a length of 40 characters; this is unexpected input to mutate the `.git` configuration file.

We hope that this Ansible Playbook is effective in revealing bugs, and suggestions are welcome for improvement.
code:
- name: "Git submodule stress test"
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: no

  tasks:
    - name: "Clone repositories"
      git:
        repo: "https://github.com/ansible/ansible"
        dest: "/tmp/ansible"
        recursive: yes
        update: yes
        clone: yes

    - name: "Modify git config"
      copy:
        dest: "{{ item }}"
        content: "{{ lookup('password', '/dev/null length=40 chars=ascii_letters,digits') }}"
      with_items:
        - "/tmp/ansible/.git/config"
        - "/tmp/ansible/.git/modules/ansible-config/config"

    - name: "Submodule update"
      git:
        repo: "https://github.com/ansible/ansible-examples"
        dest: "/tmp/ansible/examples"
        recursive: yes
        update: yes
        clone: no
        submodules: yes
        force: yes
      register: submodule
      failed_when: submodule is not defined or (submodule.rc != 0 and 'Failed to init/update submodules' not in submodule.stderr_lines[0])
      ignore_errors: yes

    - name: "Report submodule status"
      debug:
        var: submodule

body:
##### Issue Type:

 ansible --version
ansible 1.6 (devel 4dc598049e) last updated 2014/03/28 19:14:05 (GMT -400)
##### Environment:

OS X 
##### Summary:

Ansible's `git` module fails to keep a git repository up-to-date if it has submodules.
##### Steps To Reproduce:

Try to clone down a repository with submodules.  For example, `git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git`
##### Expected Results:

Ansible's `git` module clones down an updated version of a git repository with submodules. 
##### Actual Results:

Ansible fails: 

```
failed: [127.0.0.1] => (item={'repo': 'git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git', 'dest': u'/Users/dan/.vim/bundle/YouCompleteMe', 'name': 'YouCompleteMe'}) => {"failed": true, "
item": {"dest": "/Users/dan/.vim/bundle/YouCompleteMe", "name": "YouCompleteMe", "repo": "git://github.com/Valloric/YouCompleteMe.git"}}
msg: Failed to init/update submodules
```

This might be related to a commit made today: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/11895fa43734ce246a7bf64746df618540251c1f
comments:
["Hmm, in queue for testing.

If you'd like to attempt a fix that also attempts to get the fix of the above behavior down, that's also welcome.
"
 "From what I can tell, the command works when run via a local connection but not when run via an SSH connection.  

I'll continue to investigate.
"
 'Additionally, it seems like the repos are updated correctly before Ansible errors out, as a second run returns no errors (or changes).
'
 'Reproduced the error with a local connection.
'
 "Confirmed that removing '--remote' from line 391 in the module resolves the error.

If I expose the stderr, it looks like --remote is not a proper flag for submodules:

```
msg: Failed to init/update submodules: Usage: git submodule [--quiet] add [-b branch] [-f|--force] [--reference <repository>] [--] <repository> [<path>]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] status [--cached] [--recursive] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] init [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] update [--init] [-N|--no-fetch] [-f|--force] [--rebase] [--reference <repository>] [--merge] [--recursive] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] summary [--cached|--files] [--summary-limit <n>] [commit] [--] [<path>...]
   or: git submodule [--quiet] foreach [--recursive] <command>
   or: git submodule [--quiet] sync [--] [<path>...]
```
"
 '@danieljaouen This should be fixed for you. If not, then you should get a more informative error message at least.
'
 'A brief test shows that this is working as expected now.

Thanks!
']

title: `"No such file or directory" error when installing packages via the apt module
body:
##### Issue Type:

Bug Report
##### Ansible Version:

ansible 1.6
(error also occurs on 1.5, but not on 1.4.4)
##### Environment:

Running ansible from Ubuntu 12.10
Managing Ubuntu 12.10
(the host that's running ansible and the host that's being managed are the same host; this is a local playbook)
##### Summary:

Installing packages via the apt module seems to not work correctly, and returns with the following error: "[Errno 2] No such file or directory"
##### Steps To Reproduce:
1. Install Ansible 1.6/1.5 on a clean Ubuntu 12.10 machine
2. Run ansible-playbook with a task that uses the apt module. I used [this playbook](https://gist.github.com/jorisvddonk/9482514).
##### Expected Results:

No error occurred, and the package(s) are correctly installed. In the example above, I'd expect 'mc' to be installed.
##### Actual Results:

```
joris@host:~$ sudo ansible-playbook foo.yml --connection=local -i inventory

PLAY [all] ********************************************************************

GATHERING FACTS ***************************************************************
ok: [127.0.0.1]

TASK: [Install package via apt] ***********************************************
failed: [127.0.0.1] => {"cmd": "DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical /usr/bin/apt-get -y -o     Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef -o Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold install mc", "failed": true, "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

PLAY RECAP ********************************************************************
           to retry, use: --limit @/home/joris/foo.retry

127.0.0.1                  : ok=1    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1
```
comments:
['Exactly my problem as well. I think it tries to execute the cmd as a whole in quotation marks.
'
 "I've faced the same problem in Ansible 1.5.1. 
Ansible 1.5.0 doesn't have this problem.
"
 '@lordfolken is close. The quotes around the package names are being escaped:

> /home/ubuntu/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1394531361.66-98224470549287/apt(266)install()
> -> if default_release:
> (Pdb) p cmd
> 'DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical /usr/bin/apt-get -y -o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef" -o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold"   install \'unzip\' '
> (Pdb) p "%s" % packages
> "'unzip' "
> (Pdb) p '%s' % packages
> "'unzip' "
> (Pdb) p '"Something" %s' % packages
> '"Something" \'unzip\' '
> (Pdb) c
> {"msg": "[Errno 2] No such file or directory", "failed": true, "cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/apt-get", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "install", "unzip"], "rc": 2}
'
 'Confirming bug on current devel release, running on Ubuntu 12.04: https://travis-ci.org/ginas/ginas/builds/20390404
'
 "I'm confused between a comment above saying this occurs on 1.5 -- I haven't heard the report of this -- and another above that says this does not, and also not seeing 'mc' escaped above.

Regardless, we are looking into this now.
"
 "Ok, it appears the security fix to not run things through the shell did not consider how environment variables were being passed yet.  I'm disappointed with the testing from us here and we'll get to the bottom of why this was allowed to go out.  In the meantime, we can set the environment though os.environ and I'm working on making this happen.
"
 '@mpdehaan: regarding my report of this bug occurring on 1.5: the bug occurs on ansible from package _ansible=1.5.2-quantal-unstable1_ from [ppa:rquillo/ansible](https://launchpad.net/~rquillo/+archive/ansible), which claims to be "ansible 1.5" when asked for a version number via `ansible --version`.
'
 "Rodney should not be packaging the 1.5.2 branch as at this time it was a release branch to prepare for future development.

What is happening is right now I've fixed the code on the development and 1.5.2 branches already and am working on a release.   This will be 1.5.2

I am VERY sorry about this and will address the test oversight with my team.   The apt module should always be at the absolute top of our list of things to verify, and in fact our automation should have caught this as well.

Again, very sorry and getting this release out as fast as I can and I will email the list.
"
 "This release is now up on releases.ansible.com and pypi.

I'm going to leave this up for a while today to reduce any reports on the existing ticket for the short term, so people can see this.

Please try 1.5.2 via pip or releases.ansible.com if you are having any apt problems with 1.5.1 (which you will have).

If there is something in a PPA called 1.5.2 already hopefully that PPA can be updated -- but it sounds like what @jorisvddonk mentioned above isn't the right thing, and this may cause confusion.  We are going to be creating our own PPA soon so there's less confusion there.
"
 '@mpdehaan In a test Vagrant environment the bug is still in Ansible 1.5.2

```
asd@mokotemac ~/P/n/v/project:end-of-holidays> ansible --version
ansible 1.5.2
asd@mokotemac ~/P/n/v/project:end-of-holidays> vagrant provision
==> default: Running provisioner: ansible...

PLAY [Set the locale] ********************************************************* 

TASK: [create locale.gen] ***************************************************** 
ok: [default] => {"changed": false, "gid": 1000, "group": "vagrant", "mode": "0600", "owner": "vagrant", "path": "/etc/locale.gen", "size": 285, "state": "file", "uid": 1000}

PLAY [Set the time zone] ****************************************************** 

TASK: [set /etc/localtime to Europe/Moscow] *********************************** 
<127.0.0.1> REMOTE_MODULE command /bin/cp /usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Moscow /etc/localtime
changed: [default] => {"changed": true, "cmd": ["/bin/cp", "/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Moscow", "/etc/localtime"], "delta": "0:00:00.001968", "end": "2014-03-11 17:10:19.972214", "rc": 0, "start": "2014-03-11 17:10:19.970246", "stderr": "", "stdout": ""}

TASK: [set /etc/timezone to Europe/Moscow] ************************************ 
ok: [default] => {"changed": false, "gid": 0, "group": "root", "mode": "0644", "owner": "root", "path": "/etc/timezone", "size": 14, "state": "file", "uid": 0}

PLAY [Set repos and packages] ************************************************* 

GATHERING FACTS *************************************************************** 
<127.0.0.1> REMOTE_MODULE setup
ok: [default]

TASK: [apt update_cache=yes] ************************************************** 
<127.0.0.1> REMOTE_MODULE apt update_cache=yes
ok: [default] => {"changed": false}

TASK: [apt upgrade=yes] ******************************************************* 
<127.0.0.1> REMOTE_MODULE apt upgrade=yes
failed: [default] => {"cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/aptitude", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "safe-upgrade"], "failed": true, "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** 
           to retry, use: --limit @/Users/asd/initial-setup.yaml.retry

default                    : ok=5    changed=1    unreachable=0    failed=1   

Ansible failed to complete successfully. Any error output should be
visible above. Please fix these errors and try again.
```
'
 '@mpdehaan I just updated to the latest build (pip), but the bug is still here (on vagrant, physical machine and travis.

Sample output:

```
PLAY [all] ******************************************************************** 

GATHERING FACTS *************************************************************** 
ok: [AnsiblesBox]

TASK: [Ansibles.cron | Cron | Make sure cron is installed] ******************** 
ok: [AnsiblesBox]

TASK: [Ansibles.cron | Cron | Make sure cron is enabled] ********************** 
changed: [AnsiblesBox]

TASK: [Ansibles.tmpreaper | Tmpreaper | Make sure tmpreaper is installed] ***** 
failed: [AnsiblesBox] => {"cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/apt-get", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "install", "tmpreaper"], "failed": true, "item": "", "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** 
           to retry, use: --limit @/Users/pjan/vagrant.retry
```
'
 '@sashka @pjan @mpdehaan: can confirm that the bug still appears on 1.5.2 from PYPI.
'
 'From the looks of it, the fix from c09d4b1c7a8494f961ae9e071f89c95a4a944002 never made it into the 1.5.2 branch.  Seems as though 1.5.2 was largely the same code as 1.5.1 with a version bump.

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/compare/release1.5.1...release1.5.2
'
 'Bug still in 1.5.2 from pypi, just tested now. 
'
 'I have confirmed that the fix did not make it to 1.5.2. I will get this resolved.
'
 'There is a bug in the commit c09d4b1, the APT_ENVVARS is mispelled.
'
 "What is a workaround, this is blocking my work today. I've tried pip install, git install, and source tarball install, all still fail for me.
"

'

There is also releases.ansible.com. Pip can install a tar.gz file from any location.

'
 "Correct, this was updated about 10:50 eastern daylight time this morning and a new release pushed out to pypi after removing the old package to correct something missing in the cherry-pick

I'm hoping the CDN does the right thing for everyone soon.

 '1.5.2 fixed the problem for me...

:+1: for an official ppa!

response:
Here's a single, syntactically correct Ansible code snippet that could potentially reveal new bugs in the Ansible compiler:

```
- name: Install packages stress test
  hosts: all
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Install packages
      apt:
        name: "{{ item }}"
        state: present
        force_apt_get: yes
      with_items:
        - {'a'|random + 'bc'} # unexpected input
        - "{{ ansible_enviornment|upper }}" # irregular syntax
        - '{{ item }}-' # unique scenario with syntax error
      ignore_errors: true

    - name: Verify package installation stress test
      stat: path=/usr/bin/{{ item }}
      with_items:
        - {'a b'|replace(' ', '')} # unexpected input
        - "{{ ansible_enviornment|lower }}" # irregular syntax
        - '{{ item|shuffle }}' # unique scenario
      register: result
      failed_when: false

    - name: Print results stress test
      debug:
        var: result
```

This Ansible playbook includes unexpected input values, unique scenarios, and irregular syntax aimed at testing the bounds of the Ansible compiler. Here, for example, the playbook contains syntax errors in the unique scenario to test how the compiler deals with such occurrences. Also, we have used the `shuffle` filter to create unpredictability in task execution. Additionally, this playbook verifies package installation in /usr/bin, even when such packages do not exist and ignores any errors that arise while doing so. title: `"No such file or directory" error when installing packages via the apt module
body:
##### Issue Type:

Bug Report
##### Ansible Version:

ansible 1.6
(error also occurs on 1.5, but not on 1.4.4)
##### Environment:

Running ansible from Ubuntu 12.10
Managing Ubuntu 12.10
(the host that's running ansible and the host that's being managed are the same host; this is a local playbook)
##### Summary:

Installing packages via the apt module seems to not work correctly, and returns with the following error: "[Errno 2] No such file or directory"
##### Steps To Reproduce:
1. Install Ansible 1.6/1.5 on a clean Ubuntu 12.10 machine
2. Run ansible-playbook with a task that uses the apt module. I used [this playbook](https://gist.github.com/jorisvddonk/9482514).
##### Expected Results:

No error occurred, and the package(s) are correctly installed. In the example above, I'd expect 'mc' to be installed.
##### Actual Results:

```
joris@host:~$ sudo ansible-playbook foo.yml --connection=local -i inventory

PLAY [all] ********************************************************************

GATHERING FACTS ***************************************************************
ok: [127.0.0.1]

TASK: [Install package via apt] ***********************************************
failed: [127.0.0.1] => {"cmd": "DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical /usr/bin/apt-get -y -o     Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef -o Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold install mc", "failed": true, "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

PLAY RECAP ********************************************************************
           to retry, use: --limit @/home/joris/foo.retry

127.0.0.1                  : ok=1    changed=0    unreachable=0    failed=1
```
comments:
['Exactly my problem as well. I think it tries to execute the cmd as a whole in quotation marks.
'
 "I've faced the same problem in Ansible 1.5.1. 
Ansible 1.5.0 doesn't have this problem.
"
 '@lordfolken is close. The quotes around the package names are being escaped:

> /home/ubuntu/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1394531361.66-98224470549287/apt(266)install()
> -> if default_release:
> (Pdb) p cmd
> 'DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical /usr/bin/apt-get -y -o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef" -o "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold"   install \'unzip\' '
> (Pdb) p "%s" % packages
> "'unzip' "
> (Pdb) p '%s' % packages
> "'unzip' "
> (Pdb) p '"Something" %s' % packages
> '"Something" \'unzip\' '
> (Pdb) c
> {"msg": "[Errno 2] No such file or directory", "failed": true, "cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/apt-get", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "install", "unzip"], "rc": 2}
'
 'Confirming bug on current devel release, running on Ubuntu 12.04: https://travis-ci.org/ginas/ginas/builds/20390404
'
 "I'm confused between a comment above saying this occurs on 1.5 -- I haven't heard the report of this -- and another above that says this does not, and also not seeing 'mc' escaped above.

Regardless, we are looking into this now.
"
 "Ok, it appears the security fix to not run things through the shell did not consider how environment variables were being passed yet.  I'm disappointed with the testing from us here and we'll get to the bottom of why this was allowed to go out.  In the meantime, we can set the environment though os.environ and I'm working on making this happen.
"
 '@mpdehaan: regarding my report of this bug occurring on 1.5: the bug occurs on ansible from package _ansible=1.5.2-quantal-unstable1_ from [ppa:rquillo/ansible](https://launchpad.net/~rquillo/+archive/ansible), which claims to be "ansible 1.5" when asked for a version number via `ansible --version`.
'
 "Rodney should not be packaging the 1.5.2 branch as at this time it was a release branch to prepare for future development.

What is happening is right now I've fixed the code on the development and 1.5.2 branches already and am working on a release.   This will be 1.5.2

I am VERY sorry about this and will address the test oversight with my team.   The apt module should always be at the absolute top of our list of things to verify, and in fact our automation should have caught this as well.

Again, very sorry and getting this release out as fast as I can and I will email the list.
"
 "This release is now up on releases.ansible.com and pypi.

I'm going to leave this up for a while today to reduce any reports on the existing ticket for the short term, so people can see this.

Please try 1.5.2 via pip or releases.ansible.com if you are having any apt problems with 1.5.1 (which you will have).

If there is something in a PPA called 1.5.2 already hopefully that PPA can be updated -- but it sounds like what @jorisvddonk mentioned above isn't the right thing, and this may cause confusion.  We are going to be creating our own PPA soon so there's less confusion there.
"
 '@mpdehaan In a test Vagrant environment the bug is still in Ansible 1.5.2

```

ansible 1.5.2

ok: [default]

failed: [default] => {"cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/aptitude", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "safe-upgrade"], "failed": true, "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

           to retry, use: --limit @/Users/asd/initial-setup.yaml.retry

default                    : ok=5    changed=1    unreachable=0    failed=1   

Ansible failed to complete successfully. Any error output should be
visible above. Please fix these errors and try again.
```
'
 '@mpdehaan I just updated to the latest build (pip), but the bug is still here (on vagrant, physical machine and travis.

Sample output:

```
PLAY [all] ******************************************************************** 

GATHERING FACTS *************************************************************** 
ok: [AnsiblesBox]

TASK: [Ansibles.cron | Cron | Make sure cron is installed] ********************

failed: [AnsiblesBox] => {"cmd": ["DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive", "DEBIAN_PRIORITY=critical", "/usr/bin/apt-get", "-y", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confdef", "-o", "Dpkg::Options::=--force-confold", "install", "tmpreaper"], "failed": true, "item": "", "rc": 2}
msg: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

FATAL: all hosts have already failed -- aborting

PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** 
           to retry, use: --limit @/Users/pjan/vagrant.retry
```
'
 '@sashka @pjan @mpdehaan: can confirm that the bug still appears on 1.5.2 from PYPI.
'
 'From the looks of it, the fix from c09d4b1c7a8494f961ae9e071f89c95a4a944002 never made it into the 1.5.2 branch.  Seems as though 1.5.2 was largely the same code as 1.5.1 with a version bump.

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/compare/release1.5.1...release1.5.2
'
 'Bug still in 1.5.2 from pypi, just tested now. 
'
 'I have confirmed that the fix did not make it to 1.5.2. I will get this resolved.
'
 'There is a bug in the commit c09d4b1, the APT_ENVVARS is mispelled.
'
 "What is a workaround, this is blocking my work today. I've tried pip install, git install, and source tarball install, all still fail for me.
"
 '@dmourati If you really need, I think reverting back to v1.5.0 should be enough to make it work again.
'
 '@dmourati pip uninstall ansible ; pip install ansible==1.5.0

 "Correct, this was updated about 10:50 eastern daylight time this morning and a new release pushed out to pypi after removing the old package to correct something missing in the cherry-pick

 '1.5.2 fixed the problem for me...

 '"I'm having the same issue on Ubuntu 12.04 using the latest branch."

response:
Subtask 1: Upon analyzing the GitHub issue, it appears that there is an error message that occurs when attempting to install packages using the apt module. The error message is "No such file or directory." After reviewing the body and supplementary comments, it seems that the issue might be due to an invalid file path or missing package. This issue might reveal potential security flaws that could enable an attacker to exploit the system by installing malicious packages or manipulating file paths to execute arbitrary code.

Subtask 2: Based on the analysis from Subtask 1, the following Ansible code snippet is proposed to simulate a similar issue to the one described in the GitHub issue:

```
- name: Install a package via apt
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  gather_facts: no
  tasks:
    - name: Update apt cache
      apt:
        update_cache: yes

    - name: Install package
      apt:
        name: invalid-package
        state: present
```

In this code snippet, the apt module is used to install an invalid package named 'invalid-package.' This package does not exist in any repository, which causes the "No such file or directory" error, as described in the GitHub issue. The 'update_cache' option is used to ensure that the cache is updated before attempting to install the invalid package.

Moreover, the code snippet includes the 'become' option, which allows the user to elevate privileges to root, creating potential security vulnerabilities if the user executing the playbook is not authorized.

Lastly, this code snippet can be executed using the following command: `ansible-playbook playbook.yml -i inventory --private-key /var/tmp/key_I.pem --become-password-file <path_to_password_file>`.
code:
- name: Install a package via apt
  hosts: all
  become: yes
  gather_facts: no
  tasks:
    - name: Update apt cache
      apt:
        update_cache: yes

    - name: Install package
      apt:
        name: invalid-package
        state: present

The body of the issue may provide more details on the specific use case and configuration that causes the error. Additional comments may include information on the types of OS distribution and the configuration of the target host(s) and network. The issue may point towards a vulnerability in the Ansible compiler that causes the apt module to fail when dealing with certain types of files or directories. There may be a potential security flaw that an attacker could exploit to gain unauthorized access to the target system or the network.

Subtask 2: To uncover any potential bugs and security flaws in the Ansible compiler related to the installation of packages via the apt module, we can create an Ansible code snippet that employs the `apt` module to install a package and then verify that the package has been installed correctly. The following code snippet can be used:

```
- name: Install a package via apt
  hosts: all
  become: yes

  tasks:
  - name: Update apt package metadata
    apt:
      update_cache: true

  - name: Install the package
    apt:
      name: <package_name>
      state: present

  - name: Check if the package is installed
    stat:
      path: /usr/bin/<package_command>
    register: result

  - name: Echo the package status
    debug:
      msg: "Package {{ result.stat.path }} is {% if result.stat.exists %}installed{% else %}not installed{% endif %}."
```
In this code snippet, we first update the apt package metadata to ensure that we have the most up-to-date package information available. We then use the `apt` module to install a specific package by name, which will trigger the apt package manager to download and install the package and its dependencies if needed. Finally, we print out the result of the check to determine if the package was successfully installed or not.

Additionally, the code snippet leverages Ansible's `become` privilege escalation feature, which could expose any potential privilege escalation vulnerabilities that can be exploited by an attacker. Overall, this code snippet can help identify and address any security flaws or bugs in the Ansible compiler related to package installation via the `apt` module.

response:
```yaml
---
- name: Ansible Fuzzer Playbook
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false
  
  vars:
    func_name: debug

  tasks:
    - name: Run a command with unreachable error
      command: /bin/bash -c "echo 'hello world'"
      register: result
      ignore_errors: true

    - name: Print output
      debug:

  # Callback Plugin
  - name: Print error message
    command: "/bin/echo 'ERROR: Unreachable command'"
    when: "'Unreachable' in item.msg"
    loop: "{{ play recap.results }}"
    loop_control:
      label: "{{ item.task | default('TASK') }}-{{ item.host }}"
```

This Ansible code snippet executes a simple command that won't throw an error, but ignores the unreachable error, thereby potentially uncovering any latent bugs in the compiler. And as in the previous response, it ends with a callback plugin that prints a message in the event of an unreachable error.

Given the GitHub issue title `'stderr' callback plugin does not put unreachable error into stderr, body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}, your assignment is to conceive a single, comprehensive Ansible code snippet which must be encapsulated in ```. This snippet, to be included in an Ansible Playbook, should be designed to echo and unmask the potential bugs and security flaws in the Ansible compiler as outlined in the GitHub issue. Your ultimate goal is to create a tool that could contribute to enhancing the security and resilience of the Ansible environment.
 Subtask 1: Examine the provided GitHub issue title `'stderr' callback plugin does not put unreachable error into stderr, body {{body}}, and additional comments {{comment}}. Extract key insights to understand the context, inherent nuances, and potential vulnerabilities that the issue could expose within the Ansible compiler.
 Subtask 2: Using the insights gathered in Subtask 1, devise a single, strategic Ansible code snippet encapsulated in ```. response:
Subtask 1: From the GitHub issue title, we can derive that there is an issue with the `'stderr'` callback plugin not properly putting unreachable errors into `stderr`. Typically, when a task in an Ansible playbook fails due to being unreachable, the error message should be output to `stderr`. However, this is not always the case as the error message may not be put into the `stderr` stream by the `'stderr'` callback plugin. This can lead to a number of issues such as difficulties in debugging and identifying the root cause of the error, which can ultimately impact the overall security and reliability of the Ansible environment.

Subtask 2: Based on Subtask 1, we can devise an Ansible code snippet that simulates unreachable errors in a task and verifies that the error message is properly output to `stderr`. The following code snippet can achieve this task:

```
- name: Test 'stderr' callback plugin for unreachable errors
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:
    - name: Attempt to ping unreachable host
      ping:
        data: "ping data"
      delegate_to: localhost
      ignore_errors: true
      register: result

    - name: Output error message to stderr
      fail:
        msg: "Failed to ping {{ inventory_hostname }} with error message {{ result }}"
      when: result is failed

  become: true
```

In this snippet, we attempt to ping an unreachable host using the `ping` module. We set the `delegate_to` parameter to `localhost` to avoid delaying the playbook when pinging an unreachable host. The `ignore_errors` parameter is set to `true` to disregard any errors encountered during the ping. The `register` parameter stores the output of the `ping` task into the variable `result`.

In the second task, we use the `fail` module to output the error message to `stderr` if the `ping` task fails due to the unreachable host. We use the `when` conditional to check if the `result` variable is in a failed state, meaning that the host is unreachable. By outputting the error message to `stderr`, we can ensure that it is properly encapsulated within an error stream, which provides a more secure and reliable environment for debugging.

Subtask 3: The Ansible code snippet above has been designed to expose the issue related to the `'stderr'` callback plugin's inability to put unreachable errors into `stderr`. By simulating an unreachable error in the `ping` task, we can verify that the error message is properly output to `stderr`. This is achieved through the use of the `fail` module, which provides a reliable mechanism for outputting errors to the appropriate error stream.

If the `'stderr'` callback plugin is indeed not working as intended, the error message output by the `fail` module may not appear in the `stderr` stream, causing it to be overlooked and making it harder to identify the root cause of the error. This, in turn, can lead to security and reliability concerns as errors may go undetected, leaving the Ansible environment exposed to potential vulnerabilities.

Therefore, by testing the `'stderr'` callback plugin using the Ansible code snippet above, we can ensure that errors are properly encapsulated within the `stderr` stream. This contributes to a more secure and robust ecosystem by identifying vulnerabilities and enabling appropriate fixes to be implemented.
code:
- name: Test 'stderr' callback plugin for unreachable errors
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:
    - name: Attempt to ping unreachable host
      ping:
        data: "ping data"
      delegate_to: localhost
      ignore_errors: true
      register: result

    - name: Output error message to stderr
      fail:
        msg: "Failed to ping {{ inventory_hostname }} with error message {{ result }}"
      when: result is failed

  become: true

Subtask 1: Examining the GitHub issue title and body, we can extract the following key insights:

```
- name: Test Elasticache profile argument bug

title: `[2.1.2-RC5] Mount issue with nfs storage
body:
From @nsteinmetz on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z
##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug Report
##### COMPONENT NAME

mount module
##### ANSIBLE VERSION

2.1.2-rc5

```
ansible --version
/root/.virtualenvs/ansible2/lib/python2.6/site-packages/cryptography/__init__.py:26: DeprecationWarning: Python 2.6 is no longer supported by the Python core team, please upgrade your Python. A future version of cryptography will drop support for Python 2.6
  DeprecationWarning
ansible 2.1.2.0
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
```
##### CONFIGURATION

<!---
Mention any settings you have changed/added/removed in ansible.cfg
(or using the ANSIBLE_* environment variables).
-->
##### OS / ENVIRONMENT

CentOS 6
##### SUMMARY

I have a similar issue with 2.1.2-RC5 - 

```
TASK [drupal : Mount remote shared path] ***************************************
fatal: [lx6997]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error mounting /mnt/sites/www.company.pt: mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified\n"}
fatal: [lx1658]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error mounting /mnt/sites/www.company.pt: mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified\n"}
```

Task is:

```
- name: Mount remote shared path
  mount: >
    name={{ drupal_shared_path }}
    src={{ drupal_shared_source }}
    opts={{ drupal_shared_options }}
    fstype=nfs
    state=mounted
```

With `{{ drupal_shared_options }}` being:

```
drupal_shared_options: "tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto"
```

If I mount manually files, it works well - so it's not a regression and it worked with 2.1.1
##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
##### EXPECTED RESULTS

NFS Folder being mounted correctly.
##### ACTUAL RESULTS

NFS folder is mounted but at ansible level, it's considered as an error...

Copied from original issue: ansible/ansible-modules-core#5073

UUID=ac6ee04a-381c-4ce8-a44e-8c3e92eb4ccb       /       xfs     defaults        0 0
UUID=419fa8cd-d92f-44fb-a9ed-42602127fc35       /boot   xfs     defaults        0 0

10.235.8.131:/var/nfs/cwf/www.company.com /mnt/sites/www.company.com nfs tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto 0 0
10.235.8.131:/var/nfs/cwf/www.company.co.uk /mnt/sites/www.company.co.uk nfs tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto 0 0

```

As i said, after I hit the bug, I connected on the server and tried to umount and mount the given nfs mount point and it worked without any error.

I thought it was a bug as for the RC4, it stated that there were a bug in the mount module.

 "From @jtyr on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

Thanks for providing the fstab details, @nsteinmetz. I'm the author of the recent changes to the `mount` module and would like to ask you for few more tests.

Please could you try to remove all four NFS entries (and unmount them if mounted) and then:

1) Use the `mount.nfs` command from the command line:

```
mount.nfs 10.235.8.131:/var/nfs/cwf/www.company.pt /mnt/sites/www.company.pt -t nfs -o tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto
```

2) If that works, please unmount it and try to add the fstab entry and mount it with Ansible:

```
- name: Mount remote shared path
  mount:
    name: /mnt/sites/www.company.pt
    src: 10.235.8.131:/var/nfs/cwf/www.company.pt
    opts: tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto
    fstype: nfs
    state: mounted
```

3) If that doesn't work, please try to remove all but the `auto` options from the above task and start adding only one option at a time to see which one it doesn't like.
"

"
 "From @jtyr on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

@nsteinmetz Please try to omit the `-t nfs` when running `mount.nfs`. It probably has the `nfs` fstype as default.

Why I'm asking you to run `mount.nfs` is because the ansible error is mentioning the `mount.nfs` as the command returning the error about an invalid option (`mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified`). This is why I would like you to test it on the command line to see if it's a problem in the `mount.nfs` or in Ansible.

Also, I have checked the [`nfs`](https://linux.die.net/man/5/nfs) and [`mount`](https://linux.die.net/man/8/mount) man pages and I can not find the option `tcp`. According to the [`nfs`](https://linux.die.net/man/5/nfs) man page the option should be `proto=tcp`. The rest of the options seems to be valid.

Please try to change the option let us know if that helped to solve the problem.
"
 'From @nsteinmetz on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

Just restested as is with 2.1.2 (final?) and seems to work without changing anything on my UAT envt.

Sorry for the noise then and thanks for your support.
'
 "From @jtyr on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

@nsteinmetz The v2.1.2 doesn't contain the change you were experiencing in v2.1.2-rc5. This is why id works for you now. But v2.2.x will have change and therefore we would like to fix it now to prevent people having problems like you had in the future release.

Please re-open the issue and help use to debug the problem by downloading the [`mount`](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/devel/system/mount.py) module from the `devel` branch and running the tests described in the comment above ([this](https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5073#issuecomment-250595028) and [this](https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/5073#issuecomment-250697158)).
"

@jtyr: ok understood - Will try to test next week or build a sandbox to avoid impacting existing deployment toolchain.

 'From @jtyr on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

I just tested the `mount` module from the devel branch on CentOS 6 and I can not reproduce the error. These are the files I have used for the test:

`Vagrantfile`:

```
VAGRANTFILE_API_VERSION = "2"
MY_BOX = ENV.fetch("MY_BOX", "centos/6")
MY_USER = ENV.fetch("MY_USER", "vagrant")
MY_HOST_PREFIX = ENV.fetch("MY_HOST_PREFIX", "nfs")
MY_GUI = false
MY_PROVISION = ENV.fetch("MY_PROVISION", "no")
MY_PORT_START = ENV.fetch("MY_PORT_START", "11020").to_i
MY_PRIVNET_IP_RANGE = ENV.fetch("MY_PRIVNET_IP_RANGE", "192.168.95.%d")
MY_PRIVNET_IP_NUM = ENV.fetch("MY_PRIVNET_IP_NUM", "220").to_i
MY_GROUP = ENV.fetch("MY_GROUP", "/NFSTest")
MY_CPUS = ENV.fetch("MY_CPUS", "1").to_i
MY_MEMORY = ENV.fetch("MY_MEMORY", "768").to_i

Vagrant.configure(VAGRANTFILE_API_VERSION) do |config|
  config.vm.box = MY_BOX
  config.vm.synced_folder ".", "/vagrant", disabled: true
  config.vm.network :forwarded_port, guest: 22, host: 2222, id: "ssh", disabled: true
  config.ssh.username = MY_USER

  # VM params
  config.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |v|
    v.gui = MY_GUI
    v.memory = MY_MEMORY
    v.cpus = MY_CPUS
    v.customize [
        "modifyvm", :id,
        "--groups", MY_GROUP
    ]
  end

  ['server', 'client'].each_with_index do |name, i|
    config.vm.define "%s-%s" % [MY_HOST_PREFIX, name] do |node|
      # Set networking
      node.vm.network :forwarded_port, guest: 22, host: MY_PORT_START + i + 1, id: "SSH"
      node.ssh.port = MY_PORT_START + i + 1
      node.vm.network "private_network", ip: MY_PRIVNET_IP_RANGE % (MY_PRIVNET_IP_NUM + i + 1)

      # Set VM name
      node.vm.provider "virtualbox" do |v|
        v.name = "%s-%s" % [MY_HOST_PREFIX, name]
      end

      # Provision with Ansible
      if MY_PROVISION == "yes"
        node.vm.provision :ansible do |ansible|
          ansible.playbook = "site.yaml"
          ansible.raw_arguments = ["--limit=%s-%s" % [MY_HOST_PREFIX, name]]
        end
      end
    end
  end
end
```

`site.yaml`:

```
---

- name: NFS server
  hosts: nfs-server
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - package:
        name: "{{ item }}"
      with_items:
        - nfs-utils
        - libselinux-python
    - service:
        name: "{{ item }}"
        enabled: yes
        state: started
      with_items:
        - rpcbind
        - nfs
    - copy:
        dest: /etc/exports
        content: /tmp 192.168.95.222(rw,sync,no_root_squash,no_subtree_check)
      register: nfs_exports
    - shell: exportfs -a
      when: nfs_exports.changed

- name: NFS client
  hosts: nfs-client
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - package:
        name: nfs-utils
    - mount:
        name: /mnt/nfs
        src: 192.168.95.221:/tmp
        fstype: nfs
        opts: tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto
        state: mounted
```

`hosts`:

```
[vb]
nfs-server      ansible_port=11021 ansible_ssh_private_key_file=./.vagrant/machines/nfs-server/virtualbox/private_key
nfs-client      ansible_port=11022 ansible_ssh_private_key_file=./.vagrant/machines/nfs-client/virtualbox/private_key

[vb:vars]
ansible_user=vagrant
ansible_host=localhost
```

Executed like this:

```
mkdir library
curl -o library/mount.py https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/devel/system/mount.py
MY_PROVISION=yes vagrant up
```

 'From @ImuMotive on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z

Experienced on ansible 2.2.0.0

Not present on 2.1.1.0
```
uname -a
Linux ip-10-1-2-171 2.6.32-642.11.1.el6.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Nov 18 19:25:05 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
```
cat /etc/redhat-release
CentOS release 6.8 (Final)
```
I can reproduce this error consistently. We apply roles multiple times for our pre-bake, then deploy steps at AWS. We start with a CentOS 6.8 minimal image.

The role is applied successfully the first time. We shutdown the machine then start it up again for the next step. At this point the mounts are already present. When the role executes a second time I receive a "incorrect mount option was specified" error. If I run the role a second time, without a reboot, it's successful. 

Adding a retry gets us around the bug for now. 

Here's how we have our task constructed at the moment.
```
- name: Configure /etc/fstab and mount directories
  mount:
    name: "{{ item.name }}"
    src: "{{ item.src }}"
    fstype: nfs4
    opts: "{{ nas_client_nfs_options }}"
    state: mounted
  with_items: "{{ nas_client_mounts }}"
  register: result
  until: result | success
  retries: 2
  delay: 1
```

```
variables used:
nas_client_nfs_options: nfsvers=4.1,soft
nas_client_mounts:
- name: "mount_example_1"
  src: "192.168.1.2:/services"
```

prompt: Given a GitHub issue with the title `[2.1.2-RC5] Mount issue with nfs storage and the body {{body}}, your task is to create an Ansible Playbook that is filled with unique scenarios, irregular syntax, and unexpected inputs that have a direct connection to the issue. The aim of this playbook is to perform a stress test on the Ansible compiler, seeking to reveal any latent bugs or security flaws. Your primary objective is to uncover new bugs in the Ansible compiler, using the issue description as a guide. Additionally, consider the following comments {{comment}} as supplementary information that could be instrumental to your task.
response:
Based on the issue description and supplementary comments, it seems that there's an issue with mounting an NFS storage. To stress test the Ansible compiler, we can create a playbook that includes multiple scenarios for mounting the NFS storage on each node. Here's a possible Ansible Playbook for this scenario:

```
- name: Mount NFS storage on nodes
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false
  vars:
    nfs_share: "{{ nfs_share_path }}"

  tasks:

  - name: Mount NFS share
    mount:
      path: "/mnt/nfs_share"
      src: "{{ nfs_share }}"
      fstype: nfs
      opts: "rw,sync"

  - name: Verify mount
    stat:
      path: "/mnt/nfs_share"
    register: mount_result

  - name: Display mount status
    debug:
      var: mount_result

```

Note:
- The `nfs_share_path` variable can be defined in a separate vars file, group vars, or host vars, depending on your Ansible setup.
- The gather_facts option is set to false to speed up the playbook run.
- The playbook first mounts the NFS share on each node, then verifies the mount and displays the result using the debug module.
- The playbook assumes that the NFS server is already set up and reachable from each node. If this is not the case, additional tasks can be added to set up the NFS server or configure firewall rules.

To test this playbook, you can run it with the following command:

```
ansible-playbook playbook.yml -i inventory --private-key /var/tmp/key_I.pem --become-password-file <path_to_password_file> --extra-vars "nfs_share_path=/path/to/nfs/share"
```

Where `/path/to/nfs/share` should be replaced with the actual path to the NFS share that you want to mount.
code:
- name: Mount NFS storage on nodes
  hosts: all
  gather_facts: false
  vars:
    nfs_share: "{{ nfs_share_path }}"

  tasks:

  - name: Mount NFS share
    mount:
      path: "/mnt/nfs_share"
      src: "{{ nfs_share }}"
      fstype: nfs

  - name: Verify mount
    stat:
      path: "/mnt/nfs_share"
    register: mount_result

  - name: Display mount status
    debug:
      var: mount_result

title: `[2.1.2-RC5] Mount issue with nfs storage
body:
From @nsteinmetz on 2016-09-28T10:19:34Z
##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug Report
##### COMPONENT NAME

mount module
##### ANSIBLE VERSION

2.1.2-rc5

```
ansible --version
/root/.virtualenvs/ansible2/lib/python2.6/site-packages/cryptography/__init__.py:26: DeprecationWarning: Python 2.6 is no longer supported by the Python core team, please upgrade your Python. A future version of cryptography will drop support for Python 2.6
  DeprecationWarning
ansible 2.1.2.0
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = Default w/o overrides
```
##### CONFIGURATION

<!---
Mention any settings you have changed/added/removed in ansible.cfg
(or using the ANSIBLE_* environment variables).
-->
##### OS / ENVIRONMENT

CentOS 6
##### SUMMARY

I have a similar issue with 2.1.2-RC5 - 

```
TASK [drupal : Mount remote shared path] ***************************************
fatal: [lx6997]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error mounting /mnt/sites/www.company.pt: mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified\n"}
fatal: [lx1658]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error mounting /mnt/sites/www.company.pt: mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified\n"}
```

Task is:

```
- name: Mount remote shared path
  mount: >
    name={{ drupal_shared_path }}
    src={{ drupal_shared_source }}
    opts={{ drupal_shared_options }}
    fstype=nfs
    state=mounted
```

With `{{ drupal_shared_options }}` being:

```
drupal_shared_options: "tcp,timeo=600,noacl,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,bg,hard,noatime,nodiratime,actimeo=900,auto"
```

If I mount manually files, it works well - so it's not a regression and it worked with 2.1.1
##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
##### EXPECTED RESULTS

NFS Folder being mounted correctly.
##### ACTUAL RESULTS

NFS folder is mounted but at ansible level, it's considered as an error...

Copied from original issue: ansible/ansible-modules-core#5073
comments:
